text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with soft hard-boiled eggs that's
right i'm going to show you this
not-so-secret technique for getting
perfect hard-boiled eggs and by hardly
mean not too hard which unfortunately is
how many people make them in fact these
things came out so great I'm tempted to
delete our old hard-boiled eggs video I
mean I won't because it's still
generating revenue but the point is I
really should as this new method works
amazingly well
so let's go ahead get started by dumping
a little bit of water into a saucepan
and we do mean a little okay this is a 3
quart saucepan and we're only adding
like a cup and a quarter of water or
basically until the water is pinky nail
deep and then once that set we'll head
over to the stove and place that over
high heat because we want to bring this
up to a boil and the reason we're using
so little water is because we're not
going to boil these eggs we're going to
steam them since steam is hotter and
cooks much more efficiently than water
ensure I could bore you by explaining
all the science behind this once I
learned it myself
but who cares this works every time and
successful results are the best kind of
science and then what we want to do as
soon as that water starts to boil is
very carefully placing our six eggs and
we really do want to be gentle putting
these in because if you cause even a
little hairline crack in that shell it's
going to kind of explode as it steams
not violently explode but it will kind
of rupture open and not be usable so we
will place these in very carefully and
then as soon as our eggs are in the pan
we're going to do three things very
quickly we're going to cover this
immediately we're going to reduce our
heat down to medium high and we're going
to set our timer for nine and a half
minutes and believe it or not that's
basically it we're going to let those
eggs steam for nine and a half minutes
or at least that's how long I'm going to
go but depending on the texture you're
after you can certainly use the same
technique with more or less time I mean
you are the Don Draper of cooking with

the texture you're going for and we'll

it in the blog post and then what we'll
do as soon as that timer rings we will
remove the eggs from the heat and
immediately head to the sink where we're
going to hit these with cold water to
stop the cooking process which by the
way is much easier with the lid off
there we go
so we'll blast those with cold water and
then kind of pour it off and then refill
it with more cold
and like I said we're doing this to
immediately stop the cooking process
plus we want to cool these down before
we use them anyway
and that is pretty much it as soon as
these eggs cool down we can peel them
and use them or obviously refrigerate
them until we need them and speaking
appealing here's one trick I really like
after this first edition of cold water
what I'll do is pour a little bit off
and then take those eggs and kind of
crack the shell against the side of the

here and there and then I'll fill that
back up with cold water and just let
them sit like that while they continue
to cool down and what happens is that
water gets between the shell in the egg
and once these are fully chilled you'll
see they're extremely easy to peel so
that is optional and I find these
steamed eggs easy to peel regardless but
I do like that trick and I think it
helps but either way like I said once
your eggs are chilled we can pull them
out of that water and use them

going to peel off so so easily
I'm not kidding these will almost peel
themselves and then once that's peeled
let's go ahead and dry that off and grab

okay our yolk is definitely cooked

not to mention think of all the
